title: Angular momentum cons - 4 disks on light sticks

content.question: Four small disks are rigidly attached together by rods of negligible mass, as shown in the figure. The four-disk system rotates counterclockwise on a horizontal tabletop with an angular speed of <math alttext="10 radians per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>10</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>rad</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>s</mtext></math> about an axis that is located at the system’s center of mass and perpendicular to the plane of the figure. Each disk has a mass of <math alttext="0.050 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>050</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></math> and is a distance <math alttext="0.30 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>30</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></math> from the system’s center. Later, all the disks are simultaneously released from the rods and continue moving along the tabletop with negligible friction. If the size of each disk is small compared to the original <math alttext="0.30 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>30</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></math> distance from the center, what is the angular momentum of the system at the instant each disk is <math alttext="0.50 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>50</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></math> from the center of mass?
